content.raw:
One edge case:

1. Make plots on two canvases

1. click Export to bring up the dialog

1. Delete one of the canvases

1. Go back to the Export dialog, check the two thumbnails, and proceed to complete the export process - > crash

content.html:
I just confirmed with a small example on Windows that is possible to include this header, sorry for the noise. Consider my code suggestion but replace boost::filesystem::exists() with stat():

{
  std::string result = _pathAndName + "." + _extension;
  int count = 0;
  struct stat buf;

  // Check if file exists and change name accordingly
  while (stat(result.c_str(), &buf) != 1)
  {
    ++count;
    result = _pathAndName + "(" + std::to_string(count) + ")." + _extension;
  }

  return result;
}

content.raw: Actually I think we [can](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/14h5k7ff.aspx) include `sys/stat.h` for windows too. I'll try to check it later with my windows machine, but I'm not sure the plotting branch includes the latest updates to compile on windows.
content.html: Actually I think we can include sys/stat.h for windows too. I'll try to check it later with my windows machine, but I'm not sure the plotting branch includes the latest updates to compile on windows.

content.raw:
Is boost really the only solution here? I could try something like [this](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25280440/why-include-direct-h-or-sys-stat-h-conditionally-based-on-win32-or-linux):

~~~
  #ifdef _WIN32
    #include <direct.h>
  #else
    #include <sys/stat.h>
  #endif
~~~
content.html:
Is boost really the only solution here? I could try something like this:

  #ifdef _WIN32
    #include <direct.h>
  #else
    #include <sys/stat.h>
  #endif

content.raw: Does this `#include` work on Windows?
content.html: Does this #include work on Windows?

content.raw:
After exporting the same plot to pdf for a second time, a unique pdf is created with a suffix that does not collide with an existing file. However, this  behavior is different when exporting to CSV, where the new data overwrites the existing file[s] without a warning. E.g.:

After first export:

```
#!c++

caguero@bb9:/tmp$ ls -l *.csv
-rw-rw-r-- 1 caguero caguero 180084 Apr 18 10:37 Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_x.csv
-rw-rw-r-- 1 caguero caguero 172610 Apr 18 10:37 Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_z.csv
```

After second export:


```
#!c++

caguero@bb9:/tmp$ ls -l *.csv
-rw-rw-r-- 1 caguero caguero 188221 Apr 18 10:38 Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_x.csv
-rw-rw-r-- 1 caguero caguero 180539 Apr 18 10:38 Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_z.csv

```
content.html:
After exporting the same plot to pdf for a second time, a unique pdf is created with a suffix that does not collide with an existing file. However, this behavior is different when exporting to CSV, where the new data overwrites the existing file[s] without a warning. E.g.:

After first export:

caguero@bb9:/tmp$ ls -l *.csv
-rw-rw-r-- 1 caguero caguero 180084 Apr 18 10:37 Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_x.csv
-rw-rw-r-- 1 caguero caguero 172610 Apr 18 10:37 Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_z.csv

After second export:

caguero@bb9:/tmp$ ls -l *.csv
-rw-rw-r-- 1 caguero caguero 188221 Apr 18 10:38 Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_x.csv
-rw-rw-r-- 1 caguero caguero 180539 Apr 18 10:38 Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_z.csv

content.raw:
The CSV file contains the name of the `y` variable in the first row of the file but doesn't contain the name of the `x` variable, instead it only says `x`.
E.g.:

`x, double_pendulum_with_base/lower_link?world_pose/position/x`

I would expect:

`sim_time, double_pendulum_with_base/lower_link?world_pose/position/x`
content.html:
The CSV file contains the name of the y variable in the first row of the file but doesn't contain the name of the x variable, instead it only says x. E.g.:

x, double_pendulum_with_base/lower_link?world_pose/position/x

I would expect:

sim_time, double_pendulum_with_base/lower_link?world_pose/position/x

content.raw: Missing documentation for `_type`.
content.html: Missing documentation for _type.

We could use boost::filesystem::exists here and remove the stat.h dependency that I believe is not portable. Something like this (I haven't tested):

{
  std::string result = _pathAndName + "." + _extension;
  int count = 0;

  // Check if file exists and change name accordingly
  while (boost::filesystem::exists(result))
  {
    ++count;
    result = _pathAndName + "(" + std::to_string(count) + ")." + _extension;
  }

  return result;
}

content.raw: I think all the buttons look really flat and not like buttons because they don't react to mouse hover and press. I played a bit with it and hover doesn't seem to play nicely with `QGraphicsDropShadowEffect`. We might want to change the way we're generating shadows in the future. I think we can merge the functionality now and do these changes in the future.
content.html: I think all the buttons look really flat and not like buttons because they don't react to mouse hover and press. I played a bit with it and hover doesn't seem to play nicely with QGraphicsDropShadowEffect. We might want to change the way we're generating shadows in the future. I think we can merge the functionality now and do these changes in the future.

update.description: At long last, here is the plotting export dialog.
update.title: Plot export

content.raw: I think I understand why it was done like this. Each CSV file corresponds to a single variable, while a PDF holds all the variables in a single canvas. I think we should at least make this clear for the users.
content.html: I think I understand why it was done like this. Each CSV file corresponds to a single variable, while a PDF holds all the variables in a single canvas. I think we should at least make this clear for the users.

content.raw:
Related issue:

1. Open the plot dialog and add 2 canvases

1. Start plotting data on each of the 3 canvases

1. Export PDF

1. Select all, Ok

Since we didn't edit the plot names, they all have the same "Plot Name.pdf" and one is saved on top of the next, so we end up with one file, corresponding to the 3rd plot. Fixing the issue above would help, but I think we should make sure we don't overwrite an existing file. A solution could be to append `(1)`, `(2)`, etc to the file name if the file already exists.
content.html:
Related issue:

  1. Open the plot dialog and add 2 canvases

  2. Start plotting data on each of the 3 canvases

  3. Export PDF

  4. Select all, Ok

Since we didn't edit the plot names, they all have the same "Plot Name.pdf" and one is saved on top of the next, so we end up with one file, corresponding to the 3rd plot. Fixing the issue above would help, but I think we should make sure we don't overwrite an existing file. A solution could be to append (1), (2), etc to the file name if the file already exists.

content.raw:
Just to record a couple of issues I found:

* Naming scheme different for CSV and PDF (CSV includes variable name on file name, for example: `Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_z.csv` while PDF is `Plot Name.pdf`)

* Legend is cut off on the right for PDF
content.html:
Just to record a couple of issues I found:

  • Naming scheme different for CSV and PDF (CSV includes variable name on file name, for example: Plot Name-double_pendulum_with_base_lower_link:world_pose_position_z.csv while PDF is Plot Name.pdf)

  • Legend is cut off on the right for PDF
